over probably the last 20 years and it's always fun to come back the topic today
is human centered methods for improving API usability so what our API is in this
context API sir stand for application programming interfaces and by API we are
trying to use a very general term to mean things like software libraries toolkits frameworks SDK software
development kits and nowadays we also are including things that are often
called middleware or web services and we also want to include internal API so if
you're on a large software project you will be using lower level features which
are usually exposed to you as an API the key motivation for an API is so that you
can have some software resources that you don't have to personally write that you can reuse from others api's are
surprisingly important and valuable I didn't realize this when we started but there are thousands of api's just for
the web there's a site called programmable web comm which lists over 17,000 api is with like a hundred new
ones appearing every month there's a consulting company called Apogee that
says 77% of companies rate their api's is a really important part of their
business model and in fact the market for API web middleware and this is just
for the web was 5.5 billion dollars in 2014 another way of recognizing the
importance of API is I was just visiting Amazon and they mentioned to me that if you go to their financial statements
most people think of Amazon as a market income as a store in fact the store the
Amazon store lost a hundred and seventy four million dollars in the last six months but AWS which is their cloud
platform made 1.8 billion dollars so really Amazon is a web services company
that happens to have a little store as a side business and and other companies
are starting to recognize that this is a key part of their potential business
part of the evidence of that is Google actually bought the Apogee consulting company for six hundred and twenty five
million dollars last year so why should
we use human centered methods for api's well somewhat controversial my group
thinks that we can treat programmers as if they're humans and therefore we can
use techniques that we have as an HCI community established over the last twenty thirty years as successful ways
of understanding people of making things that work better for people and evaluating what what the people who are
developers are actually experiencing and we call this developer experience DX or
dev X as kind of an analogy with UX which everybody understands as an
important thing to start optimizing and api's actually have the word interface
in them and in fact they are the user interface between this body of code and the programmers who are trying to use it
so we can think about how to deal with that I like this definition of
programming if you think of it programming is basically the human activity of translating a task that you
have in your head that you're trying to get the computer to do into a representation that the computer can
understand and our claim is that the closer this the smaller this
transformation is the closer the mapping the better off you'll be and other
people have called this similar things
so in HCI we always say if the user interface doesn't work for the people it
doesn't actually work even if it doesn't have any bugs you can say the same thing about api's even if the functionality
matches what people expect if it doesn't actually operate as people want then you
can't then you should not count it as working there's been number of reported examples where the
incorrect use of ap is where people misunderstood how to use an API and used it incorrectly resulted in bugs and even
really significant security holes in software as I mentioned API sorting our
big business and it's starting to be recognized that the usability of the API
or key influencers of whether people are going to use your API is or not and so this translates into millions or
billions of dollars for certain companies and so API is usability actually is an important business asset
business advantage another thing that's important to recognize is that people
don't just use one API they're bound to be using multiple API s and they have to work together and finally even if you
don't have this really dramatic mistake in the usability of your API it can
still be a pain andrew mcbean from Google wrote this article where he
talked about how people can have death from a thousand paper cuts that the just
annoyance after annoyance in their api's eventually give makes them so sick of it that they give up and try something else
HCI human-centered methods is actually a quite a broad category most people think
of human centered methods as just usability evaluations or a bee studies
but in fact in the HCI master's program at CMU we teach all these methods plus
many more and they help you answer a wide variety of different questions you
might have about people and we found that virtually all of these can be applied to api's in fact we've done
we've applied these methods across the entire lifecycle of an api so at the
early stage where you're trying to envision or plan we've used techniques
such as contextual inquiries and interviews and surveys lab studies something called data mining where you
take a big repository of software and look through it to see what kind of patterns you can find and all of these
help you understand what the problems are at design time we have a
variety of methods to help you design your API is after you figured out what they should be doing and this includes a
natural programming process that we invented to my lab we also use graphic and interaction design as well as paper
prototyping standard HCI methods that most people wouldn't imagine you can apply to api's in fact work perfectly
well then you you know go ahead and implementers api's and then you need to
evaluate them and we again use fairly conventional HCI methods heuristic
analysis cognitive dimensions we do usability evaluations and sometimes we
even do a versus B studies of the api's themselves we haven't used these in my
lab but in andrew mcvane at google has reported that they key techniques that
they use our automatic analyses so they have tools that will automatically run
through an api and find certain problems in analogy with the lint tool for c and
they also make heavy use of peer reviews or design reviews or code reviews to
look at the api s-- and then finally after release there are lots of different mechanisms you can use log
analysis error reports feedback from users and so forth so I mentioned that
we invented the what we call the natural programming elicitation technique in my lab this was quite a long time ago we
started doing this and it's basically an idea to try and understand how your api
users are thinking about the problem you're trying to provide an API for and so what we're going for is what are
people's mental models what are people's vocabulary how do they talk about this particular design and we tend to use
blank paper tests where you just give people a piece of paper and say imagine
you had an API for X what would you how would you want to use it what would be some of the objects classes methods and
so forth the trick is to figure out a way of prompting for this without giving
away the answers so if we say you know what would be a good object for sending mail people will
say send mail and then you really haven't learned anything because they just used the words you just told them to use so it's really tricky to come up
with ways of asking the questions they don't give away the answers and that's kind of a lot of the interesting
research around this method but we have done things like understanding the API architecture trying to understand the
vocabulary people want to use and also which methods go in which classes so I
have a much larger scale project called the natural programming project that we've we've had this name since around
99 1995 but I've actually been working as James mentioned in the area of making
programming better since as far back as 78 so the goal in general of the natural
programming project is to make programming easier and the way we try to do that is by making it more natural and
we don't mean natural like natural language so we're not programming in English or French instead we're trying
to understand how people think about it and make it closer to that and we
obviously have to do studies to understand how people are thinking about it we use these studies to guide design
and we create new languages new tools and again new API is and then we iterate
iteratively evaluate and refine these and we target three classes of
programmers there's expert programmers which is most of our work we also to some extent look
at novice programmers which we define as people who are trying to become expert programmers so people who are in school
for example and separately there's a group we call end-user programmers and these are people who one colloquial way
of thinking about it or people who program because they have to and not because they want to so most computer scientists enjoy
programming that's why they went into it software engineers and so forth and they program because they want to but there
turns out to be a really large number of people in fact in a survey that we did
way back in 2005 and Chris cavite actually updated the survey just this year it's pretty consistent that
as many as 13 million people say they do programming at work even though only 3
million of them are trained as professional programmers so there are lots of different jobs that involve
doing some kind of programming for example you know writing web pages you might write some JavaScript doing
spreadsheets you might have to program doing database accesses doing data
analysis all sorts of different kind of tasks require you to do programming and
so there are lots of people who do this as part of their job not necessarily because they want to and of course
they're scientists and engineers as well and so one of the key points of this is that if you're designing api's or any
other kind of tool for programmers it's going to be used by many people who don't necessarily have a software
engineering background and so you really need to think about how other kinds of people are going to be approaching the
tests that you have available for them another way I like to describe this as as a gentle slope system and so this is
a kind of a characterization I've been using for many years the vertical axis is how hard it is to do something and
the horizontal axis is how much you can do and so thinking of Java it's pretty
hard to get started so the y-intercept is quite high there's a lot to learn if
you want to be a Java programmer but you can't do Mary very much with Java until you start learning api's and so that's

enough you have to learn how do you swing and the listener pattern and all sorts of special other things one needs
to know to use swing effectively or the networking package and have to learn sockets and all these other kinds of
things you have to learn to learn its API s so that has a very high ceiling
you can do anything you want in Java but maybe we'd like to have a lower threshold so people can get started
easier so the web is a good example of something with a lower threshold you can use Dreamweaver or templates from
different manufacturers or WordPress or whatever to get started and you can go
along pretty well and then all of a sudden you realize you need to learn CSS and HTML and that's
Waal that you'd have to overcome and then after that you want to make your page dynamic or do some data checking

same kind of thing that there's a million little libraries you have to learn and have to figure out how to get

basically the idea is that no matter where you are you can get started right away there's not a big barrier to

thing about this goal is that I've been using this chart for years and we you
know don't really have much hope of actually achieving this goal so this means I don't have to worry about
retiring I can just keep plugging at this forever and so can my students so you know there's plenty of room between
where we are and where we want to go to foster lots of interesting research approaches so our study of api's in
particular started with Jeff styluses PhD thesis where he graduated in 2009
he's now a lead API designer at IBM and he interned at the API usability group
at Microsoft in the visual studio group with Stephen Clark who kind of invented this area of API usability and his
thesis was Jeff's thesis was a lot about which programming patterns turned out to
be the most problematic and most usable and we looked at learnability error rates preferences and so forth we
studied four different three different patterns and also collaborated with s AP
and then recently Google has funded us to do some following research which I'll
tell you about as well so the Jeff's first study he called the required
constructor pattern or the creeps at call pattern and so this is the difference between being able to create
an empty object so here we're creating a foo which is empty and then we're
filling it in later so this is the create set call pattern and that's as
opposed to having a required constructor so in this case when you create a fool
you have to provide all the data that foo needs and then you're not allowed to change it afterwards or maybe you are
allowed to change it but typically you wouldn't so if you know anything about Java then a string class is immutable in
Java there's no way to change a string after you've created one whereas most of the other classes are immutable and you
can whoops you can create empty ones and fill them in so it turns out in our study that
everyone preferred the top one the create set call pattern and it seemed to
be that it fostered exploration and fostered learning better because people could learn all about foo without having
to get distracted and learning about bar first but on the other hand the security researchers were very worried about this
because the immutability pattern the second pattern is actually considered much more secure and much better for
threading if you imagine you have multiple threads if you have an immutable object it's perfectly fine to
share them amongst the threads because nobody's going to mock them up for anybody else and so this is a better
approach for security and so recently we had a follow-on research where we showed
that if you really wanted immutable objects there was a effective way of doing that which we presented at the
software engineering conference last but it was a language design not an API so I'm not going to talk about it anymore probably the most famous study
that we did was on what's called the factory pattern so normally when in
object-oriented programming when you want a new object you say new object so widget W equals new widget in the
factory pattern you're not allowed to do that you're required to go off and find this other thing called the factory and ask
it for widget so in this case you say F dot create me a widget and so this means
that when you're trying to do stuff with widgets you also have to somehow figure out that you need this other class as
well very common pattern it's used a lot in Java and.net and SCP and if you go to
books they actually recommend using this pattern in contrast we found it to be
really problematic that programmers found it very hard to use nobody ever expected it to be there and when it was
there it had a measurable impact on performance it was two to five times slower and more problematic to figure
out how to use another study we did was on object place method placement so in
any real API you're going to have multiple classes that are required multiple different groups of
functionality and you have to figure out it's a program or how to put them together and that is often very
difficult so here's an example in Java in the male program there's two classes
that coordinate together one's called the transport class and the other is called the message class and you as an
API designer have to pick one to put the send method on so which one would you pick right so usually at this point I asked
the class or the audience so how many people think it would be a better design
to put the send on the transport class okay four or five and how many people
think it'd be a better design to have the send on the message class nobody two
or three and all the other people who didn't vote well if you were an API designer you're really not allowed to abstain right you have to make a
decision this is not one of those things where you can just say well I don't care I'm not going to put it anywhere right
because you need a send method you can't send your mail so you know you have to really make a choice and so it
turns out in Java it was put on the transport method but everybody expected
it to be on the send on the message method everyone expected to be able to take your email message and send it
somewhere because that's kind of how you talk about it and the fact that it was
in the wrong place actually was very confusing to people and they would go to the message class and they couldn't find
the send method anywhere so now they were really confused about how they should go about sending emails and it
turns out that this has a really significant impact on people's performance between 2 and 11 times
slower as well as making it much harder to know what to do another interesting
observation is that the naming of classes is often very problematic so in
Java if you want to do something to the disk you might think in your head that you want to deal with files and if you

it's an interface or whatever and so it'll say oh you can't use me but I have 325
you know subclasses pick one of those all right so that's not particularly helpful you have to know that you need
